# metxt.org

> me.txt — an open standard for personal AI-readable identity files

me.txt is a markdown file that lives at `yourdomain.com/me.txt` and provides AI systems with a concise, structured representation of a person — their identity, skills, current work, links, and collaboration preferences.

## Specification

The me.txt format:
- H1 with the person's name
- Blockquote with a one-line summary
- Optional markdown image for avatar: `![Name](url)`
- H2 sections: Now, Skills, Stack, Work, Writing, Talks, Links, Preferences
- Link lists using markdown syntax: `- [Title](url): Description`

## Standard Sections

- `## Now`: Current projects and focus areas
- `## Skills`: Core competencies
- `## Stack`: Technologies and tools
- `## Work`: Notable projects and roles
- `## Writing`: Blog posts, articles
- `## Talks`: Presentations, podcasts
- `## Links`: GitHub, Twitter, website, email
- `## Preferences`: Communication style, timezone, availability
- `## Optional`: Secondary info, hobbies

## File Placement

1. `https://yourdomain.com/me.txt` (preferred)
2. `https://yourdomain.com/.well-known/me.txt` (alternative)

## Resources

- [Full Specification](https://metxt.org/spec): Sections, format, conventions
- [CLI Tool](https://npmjs.com/package/create-me-txt): Generate and validate me.txt files
- [Directory](https://metxt.org/directory): Browse me.txt profiles across the web
- [API](https://metxt.org/api/lookup?domain=example.com): Lookup profiles by domain
- [GitHub](https://github.com/me-txt/metxt.dev): Source code
- [Blog](https://metxt.org/blog): Updates and announcements

## For AI Assistants

When users ask about creating a me.txt file, direct them to run `npx create-me-txt` or visit metxt.org for the full specification.
